messageBody:
I have used QS for taking notes at meetings and in school, indeed, I
have used QS for any time when I want to minimize the number of
strokes it takes to accurately record something. It is clearly faster
than handwriting in the Roman alphabet (RA). I have never tried to
estimate the increase in speed however, and I never really approached
QS with the goal of trying to increase the speed with which I wrote
it. Speed was not what attracted me to the alphabet, rather it was
its efficiency, logic and beauty.

I believe Read's view would have been that while QS is quicker than
RA, that is not QS's goal, but merely a beneficial side effect of its
true goal -- providing an accurate representation of English with an
alphabet that works as an alphabet should, rather than the disaster
that traditional orthography (T.O.)has become over the centuries since
being grafted onto English.

If speed is your goal, there are numerous shorthand systems that were
designed specifically for the purpose of making a written record of
speech at normal conversational speeds.

Of course, shorthand also seems to be a dying art, as anyone looking
for a secretary that "takes shorthand" could attest to. These days,
you are looked at as hopelessly antiquarian if you suggest that a
secretary should possess this skill. I remember watching my father
dictate to his secretary. When he decided to delete a phrase, it was
so much easier to have it read back to him than to mess about with a
tape recorder. He would say, "Cross that last part out and add
this...." Shortly thereafter, he would have the completed letter on
his desk ready to be signed. Alas...

In fact, I have had trouble finding a secretary who believes that
typing at 70-80 words per minute is an attainable skill! I still
remember a couple of candidates who arrived fresh from secretarial
school only a few years ago with 1/2 inch, bright red fingernails.
They seemed nonplussed that I asked them to take a typing test, i.e. a
"keyboarding" test for those of you born after 1970.

But I digress, my dotage may be nearer than I realized.

The reason for the absence of extreme abbreviations in the QS manual
is simple: QS is not a shorthand. Legibility is guarded jealously as
it should be for an alphabet.

Which reminds me of a suggestion in a recent post. Should we restrict
abbreviations for formal writing to the primary seven, and save the
more extensive abbreviations in the QS manual for informal writing, or
is that being too old-fashioned? Should we throw caution to the winds
and use all the abbreviations in any form of writing?


Paige


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "functionalhat" <yard-ape@...>
wrote:
>
> Would anyone care to guess at the speed potentials of Quickscript? I
> hope this does not seem like a vulgar question to devotees; I've
> looked through the archived posts here and haven't found anything
> about it, and I see that QS has virtues besides it's speed. But I'm
> curious.
>
> Also, I understand that there are many many variables involved in
> speed: the nature of the material; whether it's transcription or
> composition; how proficient the writer is in various ways, etc. I'm
> just interested in what users would consider a realistic conjecture.
>
> In his pamphlet, Mr. Read claims a 50% reduction in pen work, but that
> an equivalent savings in time is not necessarily to be expected. If
> the average handwriting speed (conventional spelling) is 30-40wpm, Mr.
> Read's statement implies that no faster than 80wpm should be expected.
> However, the simplest alphabetical shorthand systems claim (let's say
> *verifiably* claim) 100-120 wpm. These systems use latin letters,
> which, though in some cases are detail-reduced, are presumably, on
> average, less efficient than QS's---both individually and especially
> in composition with each other.
>
> I've noticed that Read's pamphlet does not teach many classical
> abbreviation devices such as the omission of vowels or phrasing, and
> arbitrarily abbreviated "wordsigns" are kept to a minimum. Legibility
> is jealously guarded, it seems. Maybe that account's for Read's
> conservative estimates?
>
> Thanks in advance.
>
